channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Who Would Replace Kamala Harris in the Senate for California? Let the Jockeying Begin
item.description: As the Democratic vice-presidential nominee hits the campaign trail, a race to replace her kicks off.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Senator Kamala Harris is elected vice president, her rise will leave an opening for her seat in the United States Senate.

item.title: Protesters Blocked ICE Buses in Oregon. Federal Agents Responded in Force.
item.description: Using crowd-control weapons, agents were able to extract people who were detained on one of the buses after hundreds of protesters in Bend, Ore., blocked the vehicles from moving.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker

item.title: How Trump’s Push to Reopen Schools Backfired
item.description: Distrust of the president and his motives hardened the conviction of some educators that teaching in person was unsafe, helping drive union opposition.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: LM Otero/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mr. Trump said the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on how to safely reopen schools were “impractical” and should be revised.

item.title: A Florida Sheriff Has Ordered His Deputies Not to Wear Masks
item.description: The sheriff forbade his deputies from wearing masks while on duty, with some exceptions, and also barred visitors to his offices from wearing them.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: More states and cities are moving to require face coverings. In Miami Beach, Fla., above, officials have issued more than $14,000 in fines to people who have refused to wear masks.

item.title: Obesity Raises the Risk of Death From Covid-19 Among Men
item.description: Obesity is not an independent risk for women, according to a new study, perhaps because their fat is distributed differently.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura/Getty Images
item.media:description: Medical workers prepared to transport the body of a patient who died of Covid-19 at the United Memorial Medical Center in Houston.

item.title: McConnell Appears Set to Quietly Suffocate Long-Debated F.B.I. Surveillance Bill
item.description: The Senate majority leader has long been a strong supporter of extending Patriot Act provisions. This year, he’s letting them remain lapsed.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, has given no sign that he intends to move forward with the legislation when Congress briefly reconvenes after its annual August vacation.

item.title: Top Homeland Security Officials Are Serving Illegally, G.A.O. Says
item.description: The acting secretary of homeland security, Chad F. Wolf, and his deputy, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli, were appointed to their posts in violation of federal law, Congress’s watchdog determined.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chad F. Wolf, the acting secretary of homeland security, preparing to testify before Congress earlier this month.

item.title: Ex-F.B.I. Lawyer Expected to Plead Guilty in Review of Russia Inquiry
item.description: Prosecutors did not reveal any evidence of the kind of broad anti-Trump conspiracy among law enforcement officials that the president has long alleged.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: F.B.I. investigators first obtained court permission in October 2016 to wiretap a Trump campaign adviser, and the court agreed to extend the order three times.

item.title: This Star Looked Like It Would Explode. Maybe It Just Sneezed
item.description: The mysterious dimming of the red supergiant Betelgeuse is the result of a stellar exhalation, astronomers say.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: European Southern Observatory/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken in February by the European Southern Observatory’s Very Large Telescope of the star Betelgeuse, in the constellation Orion, which has been observed to be dimming.

item.title: Clinical Trials of Coronavirus Drugs Are Taking Longer Than Expected
item.description: Antibody trials sponsored by Regeneron and Eli Lilly are off to a slow start because of a dearth of tests, overwhelmed hospitals and reluctant patients.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A monoclonal antibody clinical trial site in Mesa, Ariz., is kept bare to ensure a faster disinfection process. Testing delays, difficulty finding trial sites and challenges to enrolling patients have hindered the research.

item.title: A Black Marxist Scholar Wanted to Talk About Race. It Ignited a Fury.
item.description: The cancellation of a speech reflects an intense debate on the left: Is racism the primary problem in America today, or the outgrowth of a system that oppresses all poor people?
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:credit: Eric Sucar/University of Pennsylvania
item.media:description: Adolph Reed teaching a class at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is now a professor emeritus, in April 2019.

item.title: ‘We’ve Already Survived an Apocalypse’: Indigenous Writers Are Changing Sci-Fi
item.description: Long underrepresented in genre fiction, Native American and First Nations authors are reshaping its otherworldly (but still often Eurocentric) worlds.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cherie Dimaline near her home in Midland, Ontario. “There’s a big push now for the telling of Indigenous stories,” she said.

item.title: Luchita Hurtado, Artist Who Became a Sensation in Her 90s, Dies at 99
item.description: For years she worked in the shadow of her artist husbands and more famous peers, painting at night when the children were asleep. Then a trove of her work was discovered.
item.dc:creator: Karen Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Laure Joliet
item.media:description: The artist Luchita Hurtado with some of her work in 2018. Her work spanned Surrealism, Mexican muralism, feminism and environmentalism.

item.title: Michael Cohen releases details about his forthcoming memoir.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Corey Sipkin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael D. Cohen upon his return home from prison in July.

item.title: How to Vote by Mail in California
item.description: Friday: Although Californians have a leg up, turning out voters during a pandemic will still be a challenge. Also: The jockeying for Kamala Harris’s seat has begun.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: A man casting his ballot on the eve of Super Tuesday, at a voting center in Sacramento in March.

item.title: Who from California would replace Kamala Harris in the Senate?
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Kamala Harris is elected vice president, her rise will leave an opening for her Senate seat.

item.title: Biden Urges Mandatory Masks, and Trump Pushes Birtherism
item.description: And Trump revives a racist conspiracy theory: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Trump vs. the Post Office
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarah Miler sorting ballots for Washington State’s primary last week.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates
item.description: With tax revenues plummeting, states could face a cumulative budget gap of $555 billion through the 2022 fiscal year, according to one estimate.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Women Who Fought Against the Vote
item.description: To understand the suffragists, and why their battle took so long, you also have to understand the anti-suffragists.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler

item.title: In Prison, Learning Magic by Mail
item.description: A deck of cards cut from milk cartons. A wand made with medical tape. How a group of inmates learned “the magic of magic.”
item.dc:creator: Annalisa Quinn and Vincent Tullo
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: Fighting for the Vote With Cartoons
item.description: Cartoonists used the press to battle anti-suffrage stereotypes and create a new image for the movement to enfranchise women.
item.dc:creator: Anna Diamond

item.title: Tackling a Century-Old Mystery: Did My Grandmother Vote?
item.description: Had she, in the throes of segregation and suffrage, cast a hard-won vote? I needed to know.
item.dc:creator: Martha S. Jones

item.title: Families Priced Out of Coronavirus ‘Learning Pods’ Seek Alternatives
item.description: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shy Rodriguez with her sons, Shawn Pagan, 11, left, and Jaiden Pagan, 8, at their home in Wilkes-Barre, Pa. Ms. Rodriguez has been trying to recruit other parents for a “pool” that would share child care responsibilities.

item.title: Coronavirus: When Will Long-Term Care Facilities Reopen to Visitors?
item.description: Struck hard by the pandemic, long-term and assisted living facilities shut their doors to outsiders. Many still have not reopened.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cathy Baum, right, and her husband, Mark, visited her mother, Paulette Becker, at Tall Oaks Assisted Living in Reston, Va., earlier this month.

item.title: How Queer Women Powered the Suffrage Movement
item.description: For many suffragists, scholars have found, the freedom to choose whom and how they loved was tied deeply to the idea of voting rights.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: How 14 Elephant Seals Assisted an Antarctic Ice Study
item.description: Mapping currents in the Southern Ocean is vital to monitoring climate change, but hard to conduct. So scientists turned to seals for help.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Michel & Gabrielle Therin-Weise/Alamy
item.media:description: A male southern elephant seal on South Georgia Island. The seals have become scientific collaborators, helping track under-ice ocean currents in Antarctica’s marginal ice zone.

item.title: One I.C.U., Five Patients: A Different View of the Virus’s Toll
item.description: With exclusive access in a Houston hospital, a Times team documented the impact of the health crisis on Hispanic families, in words, images and graphics.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: In an intensive care unit of Houston Methodist Hospital in July, Hector Rodriguez Montes works with a musical therapist who records his heartbeat to make a song for one of his sons. He received chemotherapy and a bone marrow transplant for symptoms related to metastatic cancer, then tested positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Man Charged With Murdering 4-Year-Old Whose Killing Prompted U.S. Anti-Crime Operation
item.description: The Justice Department last month named an operation to combat violent crime in cities after LeGend Taliferro, who was shot and killed while he slept in an apartment in Kansas City, Mo.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Andrew Harnik/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Trump held a photo of LeGend Taliferro at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Encourages Racist Conspiracy Theory About Kamala Harris
item.description: President Trump said he heard that Ms. Harris, the presumptive Democratic vice-presidential nominee born in California, was not eligible for the ticket, repeating a theory that is rampant among his followers. Constitutional scholars quickly called his words false and irresponsible.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in effect revisited an old tactic on Thursday: spreading a race-based and anti-immigrant crusade he began nearly a decade ago, when he began sowing distrust in the background of President Barack Obama, who was born in Hawaii.

item.title: Highest Rates of New Coronavirus Cases in U.S. Found in South Texas
item.description: “When the state opened, that’s when we saw the infection rate increase dramatically,” one city health official in the region said of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez, Mitch Smith and James Dobbins
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Covid-19 ward at Starr County Memorial Hospital, a rural hospital in Rio Grande City, Texas. It is the only hospital in Starr County, which has the highest coronavirus death rate in the country.

item.title: Tom Perez and the Democrats' First Virtual Convention
item.description: We talked to Tom Perez, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to find out.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images

item.title: In 'Disloyal,' Cohen Promises Sordid Tales Trump ‘Does Not Want You to Read’
item.description: In his memoir, “Disloyal,” Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s onetime lawyer and fixer, claims that he had unique access to Mr. Trump, a man with “no true friends.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: Disloyal: The True Story of the Former Personal Attorney to President Donald J Trump (Book)
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
item.media:description: Michael D. Cohen wrote much of “Disloyal” on yellow legal pads by hand from Otisville Federal Prison.

item.title: Trump Makes Clear His Opposition to More Money for USPS to Support Mail Voting
item.description: The president’s remarks fueled alarm among Democrats that he is seeking to undercut the election and sow confusion about the outcome.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Hailey Fuchs
item.media:credit: Mike Blake/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump has assailed the Postal Service in recent months, growing increasingly critical of mail-in voting and issuing repeated warnings about the possibility of election fraud.

item.title: How Joe Biden Chose Kamala Harris as VP
item.description: Joe Biden winnowed a large list of candidates to four finalists before settling on Kamala Harris, in a process shaped by questions of loyalty. He is eyeing other contenders for top administration jobs.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: No candidate scored as highly as Senator Kamala Harris on the Biden campaign’s core criteria for a running mate, including her strength as a debater and ability to help him win the White House.

item.title: Biden, Seizing on Masks as a Campaign Issue, Calls for a Mandate
item.description: Joe Biden said wearing a mask was “about your responsibilities as an American” as he and his new running mate, Kamala Harris, drew a contrast with President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. with Senator Kamala Harris on Thursday at a briefing on Covid-19 from public health experts.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Deaths are climbing in the U.S., and data suggests the official toll is an undercount.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: U.S. Labels Chinese Language Education Group a Diplomatic Mission
item.description: State Department officials said the move was aimed at informing American schools of potential propaganda from the government group’s programs, largely known as Confucius Institutes.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the Trump administration was seeking “fair and reciprocal treatment” from the Chinese government on creating open access to educational resources.

item.title: In Derecho’s Wake, More Than 250,000 in Midwest Struggle Without Power
item.description: Residents in Iowa, Illinois and surrounding states were still without electricity days after Monday’s storms brought hurricane-force winds.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch, Aimee Ortiz and John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Andy Abeyta/The Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Laurie Berdahl among downed limbs at her home in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, this week after a derecho wind storm.

item.title: Anxiety and Depression Rises Among Young Adults, Blacks and Latinos in Pandemic
item.description: A new C.D.C. survey indicates that young people, as well as Blacks and Latinos of all ages, are showing signs of deteriorating mental health and some are resorting to substance abuse.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Cam Bonelli/The Hattiesburg American, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A freshman dorm at the University of Southern Mississippi last week.

item.title: Pompeo Says He and Military Warned Russia on Bounties for Killing U.S. Troops
item.description: The secretary of state’s acknowledgment came as a new detail surfaced about the intelligence that led to the C.I.A. assessment.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Igor Kupljenik/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: “If the Russians are offering money to kill Americans or, for that matter, other Westerners as well, there will be an enormous price to pay,” Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said.

item.title: Justice Dept. Accuses Yale of Discrimination
item.description: The Trump administration said the university discriminated against Asian-American and white applicants. Yale defended its practices and vowed to maintain them.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:credit: Andrew Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Yale University campus in New Haven, Conn. Yale is the second Ivy League school the Trump administration has confronted over its admissions policies.

item.title: Tropical Storm Josephine Forms in the Atlantic
item.description: The 10th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, Josephine is not expected to hit the Caribbean islands or the mainland United States, according to the National Hurricane Center.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: NOAA
item.media:description: Tropical Storm Josephine formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Thursday. “Right now, we don’t expect this to be a land threat,” a meteorologist said.

item.title: Winning the Right to Vote Was the Work of Many Lifetimes
item.description: It took generations of women — mothers and daughters, leaders and followers — to secure the 19th Amendment.
item.dc:creator: Kate Clarke Lemay

item.title: Don’t Like What You See on Zoom? Get a Face-Lift and Join the Crowd
item.description: Cosmetic surgeons say business is booming after elective surgery opened up, with quarantine proving a time to heal in secrecy from renovation of face and body.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrice Solorzano, right, and her daughter, Jena, each took advantage of the solitude of quarantine to get cosmetic surgeries.

item.title: You Probably Won’t Catch the Coronavirus From Frozen Food
item.description: Reports that the virus was detected in a trans-continental shipment of frozen chicken wings sparked concerns online. But experts aren’t worried.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Nataliia Rumiantseva/Alamy
item.media:description: Samples taken from chicken tested positive for coronavirus RNA, but that doesn’t mean the virus was transmissible.

item.title: Trump Eliminates Major Methane Rule, Even as Leaks Are Worsening
item.description: The weakening of Obama-era efforts to fight climate change amounts to a gift to many oil companies. Researchers warn that the decision ignores science.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Jessica Lutz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rollback marks the last major Obama-era climate-change regulation to be weakened by the administration.

item.title: Fortnite Creator Sues Apple and Google After Ban From App Stores
item.description: Epic Games, the maker of the popular game, provoked the tech giants by violating their policies, then released a social media campaign and lawsuits to confront them.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Kellen Browning and Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Epic Games
item.media:description: Fortnite has become an enormous enterprise, and Epic Games announced in May that it had more than 350 million registered players.
